expanded_description: Not all relationships are the same. Some involve quantities that can only take on specific, separate values—like the number of students in a class. Others can take on any value within a range—like the temperature throughout a day. This distinction between discrete and continuous relationships is fundamental to understanding data, functions, and real-world modeling.

core_concept.principle: A discrete relationship has a domain consisting of distinct, separate values—often integers or countable quantities. A continuous relationship has a domain that includes all real numbers within an interval—any value is possible. The graph of a discrete relationship is a set of unconnected points; the graph of a continuous relationship is a connected line or curve.
core_concept.explanation: Think of discrete relationships as things you can count: apples in a basket, people in a room, steps on a staircase. You can't have 2.5 people or 3.7 apples (in whole contexts). Continuous relationships are things you can measure: height, weight, time, temperature. You can have 5.27 feet or 98.6 degrees. The graph of discrete data looks like dots on a page; continuous data connects into a smooth line or curve.

sections.introduction: Discrete relationships involve quantities that can only take on specific, separate values. These are typically things you can count.

introduction_image.alt: Examples of discrete quantities: coins, people, books
introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.7.2: Discrete quantities are countable.

key_concept.definition: A discrete relationship is one where the domain consists of distinct, isolated values—often integers or whole numbers. The graph of a discrete relationship is a set of unconnected points. Discrete relationships typically arise from counting situations: number of students, number of cars, number of tickets sold.
key_concept.context: Discrete relationships are everywhere in real life whenever we deal with countable items. The key feature is that between any two valid inputs, there are gaps where the function is not defined. You can't have 2.3 students, so those x-values simply don't exist in the domain.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Discrete Relationships

image.alt: Various scenarios to classify as discrete or not

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each situation represents a discrete relationship. Explain why.
a) Number of students in a classroom
b) Height of students in a classroom
c) Cost of buying $x$ movie tickets at $\$12$ each
d) Amount of water in a swimming pool over time
e) Scores on a multiple-choice test (0-100, whole points)

step_by_step.explanation: You can have 25 or 26 students, but not 25.5. This is countable.
Height can be any value within a range (e.g., 152.3 cm, 167.8 cm). Measurable, not countable.
$C(x) = 12x$, but $x$ must be whole number of tickets. Domain is discrete.
Water volume can be any value—it changes continuously as water flows.
Scores are whole numbers 0-100. You can't score 85.7 on a test with only whole-point questions.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Discrete, b) Continuous, c) Discrete, d) Continuous, e) Discrete
worked_examples.concept_applied: Discrete relationships involve countable quantities where fractional values don't make sense.

sections.introduction: Continuous relationships involve quantities that can take on any value within an interval. These are typically things you measure.

introduction_image.alt: Examples of continuous quantities: temperature, height, time
introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.7.8: Continuous quantities are measurable.

key_concept.definition: A continuous relationship is one where the domain includes all real numbers within an interval. Between any two points in the domain, there are infinitely many other valid inputs. The graph of a continuous relationship is a connected line or curve without gaps.
key_concept.context: Continuous relationships model real-world measurements: time, distance, temperature, weight. These can always be subdivided into smaller and smaller units. The graph is drawn as a solid line or curve to show that every point on the curve corresponds to a valid input-output pair.

Any value within range is possible
Examples: time, distance, temperature, weight

principles.statement: A continuous relationship has no gaps in its domain. Between any two x-values in the domain, you can find another x-value that also works. The graph can be drawn without lifting your pencil.
principles.application: When graphing continuous relationships, draw a solid line or curve. Don't leave gaps unless there are domain restrictions.

sections.introduction: The most visible difference between discrete and continuous relationships is how they appear on a graph.

introduction_image.alt: Side-by-side: discrete points vs continuous line
introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.7.15: Visual comparison of discrete and continuous graphs.

key_concept.definition: Discrete graphs consist of separate, unconnected points. Continuous graphs are drawn as solid lines or curves with no breaks. The presence or absence of connections between points tells us whether values between them are meaningful.
key_concept.context: When you see a graph, the way it's drawn conveys information. Connected lines suggest you can interpolate between points; isolated dots suggest you cannot. This is crucial for correctly interpreting graphical data.

sections.section_title: 3.7.4 Domain and Range in Discrete vs Continuous
sections.introduction: The distinction between discrete and continuous affects how we describe domain and range.

key_concept.definition: For discrete relationships, domain and range are sets of specific values, often written as lists: $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$. For continuous relationships, domain and range are intervals, written using interval notation: $[0, \infty)$ or $[-2, 5]$.
key_concept.context: The way we write domain and range signals whether the relationship is discrete or continuous. A list suggests discrete; an interval suggests continuous.

worked_examples.title: Writing Domain and Range for Discrete vs Continuous

image.caption: Figure 3.7.27: Write domain and range for each.

worked_examples.problem:
For each relationship, write the domain and range using appropriate notation:
a) Number of hours studied (0 to 5 hours, any time possible)
b) Number of correct answers on a 10-question quiz
c) Height of a ball thrown in the air from $t=0$ to $t=4$ seconds
d) Cost of buying $x$ items at $\$5$ each, up to 10 items

step_by_step.step: a) Hours studied (0 to 5, any time)
step_by_step.explanation: Continuous - can study 2.5 hours, 3.75 hours, etc.
step_by_step.calculation: Domain: $[0, 5]$, Range: $[0, \infty)$ (or specific if function given)

step_by_step.explanation: Discrete - can only get whole numbers 0 through 10

step_by_step.step: c) Height of ball from $t=0$ to $t=4$
step_by_step.explanation: Continuous - time and height can be any values in intervals
step_by_step.calculation: Domain: $[0, 4]$, Range: depends on function but continuous interval

step_by_step.step: d) Cost of $x$ items at $\$5$ each, up to 10 items
step_by_step.explanation: Discrete - $x$ must be whole number of items

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Domain $[0,5]$, Range continuous interval
b) Domain $\{0,1,2,...,10\}$
c) Domain $[0,4]$, Range continuous interval
d) Domain $\{0,1,...,10\}$, Range $\{0,5,...,50\}$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Discrete → set notation (list). Continuous → interval notation.

worked_examples.problem: A company tracks its daily sales over a month. Is this relationship discrete or continuous? Explain two different ways this could be interpreted.

sections.introduction: Even mathematical functions can have discrete domains if we restrict them to specific input values.

introduction_image.alt: Same function rule with discrete vs continuous domain
introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.7.35: Function with different domain types.

key_concept.definition: A function $f(x) = \text{(rule)}$ can have a continuous domain (all real numbers or an interval) or a discrete domain (only specific x-values). The function rule may be the same, but the domain determines whether the graph is connected or just points.
key_concept.context: For example, $f(x) = 2x$ with domain all real numbers is continuous. The same rule with domain $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$ is discrete—only four points exist.

image.alt: f(x)=2x with continuous domain (line) and discrete domain (points at integers)
image.caption: Figure 3.7.36: Same rule, different domain types.

worked_examples.problem:
A student created graphs for two situations. Identify whether each graph is correct or incorrect. If incorrect, explain why and describe the correct graph.

step_by_step.explanation: Number of books is discrete (countable). There is no data between months. Connecting implies books were read between months, which doesn't make sense.
step_by_step.calculation: Incorrect. Should be points only, no line.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Incorrect - discrete data should not be connected. b) Incorrect - continuous data should be connected.

summary: Relationships can be classified as discrete or continuous based on their domain. Discrete relationships involve countable quantities where inputs can only take specific, separate values—typically integers or whole numbers. Their graphs consist of unconnected points, and domain/range are written as sets (e.g., $\{1, 2, 3\}$). Examples include number of students, tickets sold, or items produced. Continuous relationships involve measurable quantities where inputs can take any value within an interval. Their graphs are connected lines or curves with no gaps, and domain/range are written using interval notation (e.g., $[0, \infty)$). Examples include time, temperature, height, and weight. The same function rule can produce either a discrete or continuous graph depending on the specified domain. When graphing, it's essential to connect points for continuous data and leave points unconnected for discrete data. Understanding this distinction is crucial for correctly modeling real-world situations and interpreting graphical information.
